Begin with the game you woke up in a room which resembles an typical hotel room, then some banging on the door begins the great adventure of our heroine Chell. A sudden shake-off of the room which reveals the room is actually one container of 10 thousand people multi-complex. The show begins with an tremendous fashion. It appeals the player right away as if it is inviting them into the story.

And right away do you also feel the witty sarcasm which exists throughout the entire game. When the robot manager tell you: `This is art, stare at the art for 5 seconds.' and then plays classical music, it just makes me smile. The script writers are geniuses. The lines are comical but not too funny, and with a sense of dark humor. The robot themselves are always joking around with the death or termination of themselves, and sometimes to each other too. Almost childish but not overdone. Especially GLaDOS herself is a very charming character, I have to confess I fell in love with GLaDOS when she tried to talk Wheatley into a paradox, and mumbling "dont think about it dont think about it". It's just so cute.

The story and background setting are definitely deepened deliberately this time. When I played the first three chambers I was kind of worried they are just remaking Portal 1 - because I played 2 right after 1 so I could remember the puzzles as the same. Gladly they weren't! It's a fairly lengthy brand new game - about 8 hours - and every minute of it worths it. They put a lot of effort laying the background and showing the player how Aperture and the facility come to be. They laid huge architectural work for the game, I couldn't even imagine how big the facility is because it was so massive, there are so many rooms which you can't see the top end or the bottom end - which surprisingly reminds me of BioShock not at the time of playing but now. I've seen Valve done this large-world trick before in Half-Life 2, and I know they are getting good at it because this one is even better.

Music is great, not repetitive and well paced. Voice acting is tremendous, both Wheatley and GLaDOS.

The end game was also very good (and surprising!). I'm very happy that they didn't make the final boss very hard - after all, who would want to fight a difficult boss after solving all the puzzles? The tired player deserves a relaxed good show.

10/10, I haven't felt this kind of excitement for years, and Portal 2 brought it to me. It's a fine piece of work and I strongly recommended it.

Ps: I haven't played the multiplayer yet, but I heard it's very good too.

A great successor to Portal. It adds just enough to make it feel like a new experience but not so much that it is completely different. Basically what you do in Portal 1 + 2 is interact with 3D environments in order to solve puzzles and achieve your end goal (of escaping the chamber). The platforming elements of the game are light and can be handled equally with keyboard/mouse and with a controller. The puzzles are "delightfully challenging". I think the main story mode can be completed in 10 hours or less.

If you're considering getting Portal 1 or Portal 2, I would recommend playing through Portal 1 first... unless you only want to do multiplayer, then go with 2.

Ma wszystko, czego by się chciało oczekiwać od gry dla jednego gracza. Specyficzny humor, na bardzo wysokim poziomie, zagadki, wymagające chwili zastanowienia, ale też mające logiczne rozwiązania, fabułę wartą uwagi, wliczając w nią wątki poboczne. Jeżeli Portal nazwałbym grą wyśmienitą, to jego druga część jest jeszcze lepsza, biorąc wszystko to, co najlepsze w oryginale i dodając właśnie to, czego pierwszej części brak. Jest to gra, na której kontynuację czekałbym z utęsknieniem, jednak chyba wolę wrócić do tej pozycji jeszcze raz, przejść całą grę ponownie za jakiś czas, niż usłyszeć o tym, że powstanie Portal 3. A to dlatego, że gra jest tak idealnie zamknięta, że lepiej się chyba nie da. Suma sumarum - nic tylko kupować, ściągać, grać!

Portal 2 est un excellent jeu, bien meilleur que le premier. En plus d'avoir un scénario beaucoup plus travaillé et plus intéressant (j'ai bien apprécié l'humour des scénaristes), les éléments de gameplay qui y sont rajoutés rendent les tests plus diversifiés et plus nombreux, augmentant par conséquence la durée de vie du titre (~3h00 pour Portal et ~8h00 pour Portal 2, sans que je complète les objectifs secondaires). 
Certaines salles de test sont assez complexes sans etre insurmontables pour autant, les graphismes sont soignés et la bande-son est très bonne (surtout le générique de fin :3).
Je pense que Portal 2 mérite la bonne réputation qu'il a auprès des joueurs et qu'il n'est pas forcément nécessaire d'avoir jouer au 1 pour apprécier celui-ci (bien que certaines références soient présentes). Ce jeu vaut vraiment la peine qu'on s'y intéresse, mais si vous n'aimez pas les jeux où il faut un minimum de réflexion, passez votre chemin ou vous pourriez etre déçu.

Il go over certain pros and cons to give you an idea of the game:

Audience: Most people, I originally got this game as a kid, and can say that this game works just as well then as it does now. The uniqueness makes it so that really, everyone should give it a try.

Graphics: Oh lord, some of the best graphics seen from Valve, and sadley, some of the last. Also, this game can run on a potato (heh) with minimal problems.

Difficulty: I find it somewhat challenging for the first 2 playthroughs, it gets pretty intense, but after about 4 playthoughs, your brain can remember every bit of the entire map and puzzles in general, making it extremely easy.

Time you will be sucked into this game: Depends, for me, I alsways get the mood to do a run of Portal (and 2) several times a year, 

Story: Honestly, not the most powerful part of the game, but it holds together, and ends with a crazy ending that is constantly hinted to you (mainly in the 2nd act) the entire game. Overall, it's fairly well paced, although, the 2nd act streches out a bit longer than I prefered on my first playthrough.

Anti-Cheat: Not really any I guess, but not much of a multiplayer, although, you can screw around with all the commands you want on CO-OP, not that you'll find many CO-OP games open at this point.

Bugs: Bugs, what bugs?

Overall I would give it a 9.5/10

This game... is my favorite game... EVER!!! 
The dialogs are absolutely amazing and also the jokes in them. The humour in the game is so smart but still quite easy to understand. 
First of all let's talk about the story itself. You play as the character Chell who is a testsubject in Aperture Science. Aperture Science was a old research facility where they made all kinds of crazy stuff. For example the portal gun wich you will be using a lot. But the manager (Cabe Johnson) of the place tried to build his wife (Caren) as a robot and then they created Glados. Glados turned evil and after a while let deadly nurotoxin into the research facility and killed everyone. And then the events of the first game took place when Chell got tested throughout the game until "spoiler alert" Chell manages to kill Glados and destroy most of Aperture Science. But she gets captured my a robot and draged back in. And in this game Portal 2, Chell wakes up in a room and then gets saved by a robot called Weathley (wich is my personal favorite character) he drives the room into a wall and the room gets smashed into pieces. Epic intro!!! Glados is back and you have to escape from Aperture Science... again. This story has so much backstory to it. I have read the comics and watched some interesting theories about the game.
The game is a puzzle game so the game has a lot of different puzzle levels. The levels are test chambers that you go through. The puzzles are revolutionary when you have to shoot portals on walls and ceilings to go through them to get to the end of the level (test chamber). 
Overall this game is fantstic.
